Bachelor & Maria Kaina

1.Maria Kaina: You resemble an adventurer rather than a doctor.

1.Maria Kaina: You resemble an adventurer rather than a doctor.

2.Bachelor: How is it that you know me?

2.Bachelor: How is it that you know me?

3.Maria Kaina: I saw you in a dream. Don't flatter yourself, my desires have nothing to do with that. I simply saw you take us all by the throat.

1.Maria Kaina: Today, the guilty can be charged-or so they say. Today, someone will be murdered in your name. Today, they will claim your discovery as their guideline, positive it would make any strike true...

2.Bachelor: Why are you telling me this?

3.Maria Kaina: What carrier are they talking about? Who are they planning to kill? Most importantly, why? Would that stop the plague?

3.Maria Kaina: What carrier are they talking about? Who are they planning to kill? Most importantly, why? Would that stop the plague?

4.Bachelor: Whoever it is, I want to be sure that person won't cause us any more trouble.

4.Bachelor: Whoever it is, I want to be sure that person won't cause us any more trouble.

5.Maria Kaina: Now everyone who is infected; and everyone who is infected by an infected person; and everyone who is infected by the trace of an infected person; all of them are disease carriers. This horde is multiplying by the second. Can it be stopped?

6.Bachelor: So what was it that you wanted to ask of me?

6.Bachelor: So what was it that you wanted to ask of me?

7.Maria Kaina: Olgimsky wants to burn several people-but none of them is guilty. Be especially cautious when dealing with the foreseer girl. She's no human; be prepared. Even if her blood is special, don't be rash to cry witch. She's not a shabnak. She's enchanted.

1.Maria Kaina: Tomorrow, everything will change.

1.Maria Kaina: Tomorrow, everything will change.

2.Bachelor: Is something bothering you?

2.Bachelor: Is something bothering you?

3.Maria Kaina: I feel a powerful surge of lifeforce. How strange! I expected to be overcome with it on the first day-when Simon died. But it's only happening now... Time to begin!

3.Maria Kaina: I feel a powerful surge of lifeforce. How strange! I expected to be overcome with it on the first day-when Simon died. But it's only happening now... Time to begin!

4.Bachelor: What are you talking about?

4.Bachelor: What are you talking about?

5.Maria Kaina: Nothing of importance... I love seeing how unexpectedly, peculiarly, and precisely every omen, prediction, and foretelling comes true. It's time for me to begin fulfilling my duty. Seems like my time has come, Bachelor Dankovsky!

5.Maria Kaina: Nothing of importance... I love seeing how unexpectedly, peculiarly, and precisely every omen, prediction, and foretelling comes true. It's time for me to begin fulfilling my duty. Seems like my time has come, Bachelor Dankovsky!

6.Bachelor: What are you going to do?

6.Bachelor: What are you going to do?

7.Maria Kaina: Oh, I don't know yet... It'll become apparent soon. For now I want to stay alone. I'll be sleeping. I want to dream about mother and Simon. I want to ask them questions.

8.Bachelor: Sleep.

2.Bachelor: Yes. Everything will change tomorrow.

1.Maria Kaina: I have a lot to tell you, Bachelor Dankovsky, but I dare not-until you meet my uncle Georgiy. Otherwise he'll rip my tongue out for disclosing a secret.

1.Maria Kaina: I have a lot to tell you, Bachelor Dankovsky, but I dare not-until you meet my uncle Georgiy. Otherwise he'll rip my tongue out for disclosing a secret.

2.Bachelor: Some strict morals your family has...

2.Bachelor: Some strict morals your family has...

3.Maria Kaina: They make much more sense than you may think. This is not a game, is it? For all that is holy, do speak to my uncle-and then come back to me. Otherwise the excruciating anticipation will tear my heart to pieces.

3.Maria Kaina: They make much more sense than you may think. This is not a game, is it? For all that is holy, do speak to my uncle-and then come back to me. Otherwise the excruciating anticipation will tear my heart to pieces.

4.Bachelor: All right. We cannot put your heart at stake, now can we?

4.Bachelor: All right. We cannot put your heart at stake, now can we?

4.Bachelor: Where is your uncle now?

4.Bachelor: Where is your uncle now?

1.Maria Kaina: Now listen closely. The time for collusion, secrets, and alliances has come. I am going to ask something of you. I am not used to that. I'm used to holding the reins-but you are not harnessed, so it would be unacceptable to address you in this manner. I find solace in the fact that my request will be welcome with you. It fits the style of your venture.

1.Maria Kaina: Now listen closely. The time for collusion, secrets, and alliances has come. I am going to ask something of you. I am not used to that. I'm used to holding the reins-but you are not harnessed, so it would be unacceptable to address you in this manner. I find solace in the fact that my request will be welcome with you. It fits the style of your venture.

2.Bachelor: I'm not an adventurer, and my job is no venture. I hope it never becomes one.

2.Bachelor: I'm not an adventurer, and my job is no venture. I hope it never becomes one.

3.Maria Kaina: I apologize if my words come across as mangled and silly-I am truly not used to asking. But the nature of my request demands complete and selfless humility. Just imagine me begging and kneeling! And believe me, I do feel that way.

3.Maria Kaina: I apologize if my words come across as mangled and silly-I am truly not used to asking. But the nature of my request demands complete and selfless humility. Just imagine me begging and kneeling! And believe me, I do feel that way.

4.Bachelor: No need to kneel. What did you want to talk about?

4.Bachelor: No need to kneel. What did you want to talk about?

5.Maria Kaina: Today's death was the first, but it won't be the last. Simon has opened the score of irreplaceable victims. Soon their number will multiply. I beg you to preserve the lives of several people when the lines of their fortune cross yours. Before any of them dies, there will be a moment when you will be able to intervene. I know that for a fact.

5.Maria Kaina: Today's death was the first, but it won't be the last. Simon has opened the score of irreplaceable victims. Soon their number will multiply. I beg you to preserve the lives of several people when the lines of their fortune cross yours. Before any of them dies, there will be a moment when you will be able to intervene. I know that for a fact.

6.Bachelor: Who are these people?

6.Bachelor: Who are these people?

7.Maria Kaina: That doesn't matter. What was destined to happen, will happen. You can be whatever you want to be-but not a coward choosing to hear no evil and run away from reality! I will give you a list of those I know of. These people are Bound... to you.

7.Maria Kaina: That doesn't matter. What was destined to happen, will happen. You can be whatever you want to be-but not a coward choosing to hear no evil and run away from reality! I will give you a list of those I know of. These people are Bound... to you.

8.Bachelor: Bound?

8.Bachelor: Bound?

9.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

9.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

10.Bachelor: But how is their fate... bound to mine? Did you say my victory depended on them? How?

10.Bachelor: But how is their fate... bound to mine? Did you say my victory depended on them? How?

11.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

11.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

12.Bachelor: Are you clairvoyant or something?

12.Bachelor: Are you clairvoyant or something?

13.Maria Kaina: Ah, yes... you haven't been told, have you? It didn't even cross my mind that someone may be unaware of my abilities. No one here dares doubt them-for they are evident. Yes, the Mistress of every ruling house possesses special abilities. I am learning to see the future and transform the present.

13.Maria Kaina: Ah, yes... you haven't been told, have you? It didn't even cross my mind that someone may be unaware of my abilities. No one here dares doubt them-for they are evident. Yes, the Mistress of every ruling house possesses special abilities. I am learning to see the future and transform the present.

14.Bachelor: This fact offers your words a different degree of authenticity.

14.Bachelor: This fact offers your words a different degree of authenticity.

15.Maria Kaina: Will you comply with my request? Will you save the lives of the people I name to you? Answer me... before going back to Eva.

15.Maria Kaina: Will you comply with my request? Will you save the lives of the people I name to you? Answer me... before going back to Eva.

16.Bachelor: All right. If it is truly within my power, I'll do my best to save their lives.

16.Bachelor: All right. If it is truly within my power, I'll do my best to save their lives.

16.Bachelor: How do you know that Eva had asked me to come back?

16.Bachelor: How do you know that Eva had asked me to come back?

17.Maria Kaina: I know Eva. She wants to safeguard you from my nocturnal intrigues, doesn't she? She strives to touch the mysteries of our family... to learn the game we're playing. Well, talk to her. Perhaps you two will manage to uncover some bits and pieces of the Kains' dark conspiracy against humanity. But you haven't given me an answer. What will it be?

17.Maria Kaina: I know Eva. She wants to safeguard you from my nocturnal intrigues, doesn't she? She strives to touch the mysteries of our family... to learn the game we're playing. 18.Bachelor: I will do as you ask, Maria. My honour bids me to. And you'd be better off not giving me cheek. You won't like me when I'm angry.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. 18.Bachelor: But how is their fate... bound to mine? Did you say my victory depended on them? How?

I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

12.Bachelor: Everything happens.

13.Maria Kaina: That doesn't matter. What was destined to happen, will happen. You can be whatever you want to be-but not a coward choosing to hear no evil and run away from reality! I will give you a list of those I know of. These people are Bound... to you.

14.Bachelor: Bound?

14.Bachelor: Bound?

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

17.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

13.Maria Kaina: That doesn't matter. What was destined to happen, will happen. You can be whatever you want to be-but not a coward choosing to hear no evil and run away from reality! I will give you a list of those I know of. These people are Bound... to you.

14.Bachelor: Bound?

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

Well, talk to her. Perhaps you two will manage to uncover some bits and pieces of the Kains' dark conspiracy against humanity. But you haven't given me an answer. What will it be?

16.Bachelor: Bound?

16.Bachelor: Bound?

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

19.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

13.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

9.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. 15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

16.Bachelor: But how is their fate... bound to mine? Did you say my victory depended on them? How?

I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

11.Maria Kaina: Please refer to Eva Yan with such ideas, Bachelor. She will gladly go to the Capital with you-just remind her to slip into something before she leaves the premises of her house. Well, don't let it go to your head. I will probably be able to reward you... in my own way. You won't be disappointed.

13.Maria Kaina: That doesn't matter. What was destined to happen, will happen. You can be whatever you want to be-but not a coward choosing to hear no evil and run away from reality! I will give you a list of those I know of. These people are Bound... to you.

14.Bachelor: Bound?

14.Bachelor: Bound?

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

16.Bachelor: But how is their fate... bound to mine? Did you say my victory depended on them? How?

17.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

Well, talk to her. Perhaps you two will manage to uncover some bits and pieces of the Kains' dark conspiracy against humanity. But you haven't given me an answer. What will it be?

16.Bachelor: Bound?

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

19.Maria Kaina: I don't know. I'm not a Mistress yet. The future is not as clear to me as I would prefer; but I can feel the present. I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

13.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

9.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. They are standing on the verge of their humanity, gazing into the realm where they could serve a different, higher purpose-without even knowing it. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

15.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

17.Maria Kaina: There is a tight spring of power within each of these people. Each of them can break the routine of human existence and become something greater. Moreover, they are bound to make the leap-in one way or another. That's why we call them simply the Bound.

I can already distinguish a dubious guess from the pulse of the precise knowledge devoid of words and images. These people are bound to you. Your lives are connected. I wouldn't have asked you to take care of them otherwise.

11.Maria Kaina: Yes, we have. But this place is inhabited by people of flesh and blood. Why are you so surprised?

12.Bachelor: Why the dirt and the pedestrianism? Why the disheveled walls, the rusty beams, the drain covers? Is this really what a utopia looks like?

12.Bachelor: Why the dirt and the pedestrianism? Why the disheveled walls, the rusty beams, the drain covers? Is this really what a utopia looks like?

13.Maria Kaina: Precisely. This is what differentiates a utopia from a dream. There is a 'top' in 'utopia', but don't let the word deceive you: it's all about what's down below. It requires dirt. A ruby firmament needs something to sit atop-otherwise it'd topple. A utopia can appreciate the earthly and the humane in their raw homeliness. That is why we have the blood-stained Abattoir, the Rotten Field, the dens, and Earth-the collective name of the poorer districts-itself.

13.Maria Kaina: Precisely. This is what differentiates a utopia from a dream. There is a 'top' in 'utopia', but don't let the word deceive you: it's all about what's down below. It requires dirt. A ruby firmament needs something to sit atop-otherwise it'd topple. A utopia can appreciate the earthly and the humane in their raw homeliness. That is why we have the blood-stained Abattoir, the Rotten Field, the dens, and Earth-the collective name of the poorer districts-itself.

14.Bachelor: Is that so...

14.Bachelor: Is that so...

15.Maria Kaina: A utopia needs the Cult of Bulls, a living echo of the time when the human and the bestial world sung in unison. Beastliness lies at the heart of our civilization. Dirt, blood, manure, devourment, skins, meat, and bone tools. This is what the human civilization of creators originates from.

15.Maria Kaina: A utopia needs the Cult of Bulls, a living echo of the time when the human and the bestial world sung in unison. Beastliness lies at the heart of our civilization. Dirt, blood, manure, devourment, skins, meat, and bone tools. This is what the human civilization of creators originates from.

16.Bachelor: But how is it miraculous?

16.Bachelor: But how is it miraculous?

17.Maria Kaina: Earth represents the miracle of the antropophobic Steppe merging with the human world. The Settlement represents the miracle of turning a society of devourers into a society of creators. The very logic of this town's existence is a miracle in and of itself. When the process of its creation has reached a peak, the Cathedral has been built. It's been a failure though...

4.Bachelor: Why would anyone need a utopia? It's a chimera, nothing more.

5.Maria Kaina: Probably. But luckily for us, even the most well-adjusted mechanisms fail. And the two worlds do still touch sometimes! Antibodies collide! And then they go against the law of self-preservation, merging into a wondrous symbiosis rather than dying. This is the state of Utopia-an earthly form of an unearthly miracle!

5.Maria Kaina: Probably. But luckily for us, even the most well-adjusted mechanisms fail. And the two worlds do still touch sometimes! Antibodies collide! 6.Bachelor: And so you have constructed this town? Is this what an embodied miracle looks like?

6.Bachelor: And so you have constructed this town? Is this what an embodied miracle looks like?

7.Maria Kaina: Yes, we have. We could have create a mind-boggling place of rock crystal, sapphire walls, emerald roofs, and ruby pavements; a place akin to those you're used to seeing in children's fairy-tales about fairy countries. But this place is inhabited by people of flesh and blood. Why are you so surprised?

7.Maria Kaina: Yes, we have. We could have create a mind-boggling place of rock crystal, sapphire walls, emerald roofs, and ruby pavements; a place akin to those you're used to seeing in children's fairy-tales about fairy countries. 8.Bachelor: Why the dirt and the pedestrianism? Why the disheveled walls, the rusty beams, the drain covers? Is this really what a utopia looks like?

8.Bachelor: Why the dirt and the pedestrianism? Why the disheveled walls, the rusty beams, the drain covers? Is this really what a utopia looks like?

9.Maria Kaina: Precisely. This is what differentiates a utopia from a dream. There is a 'top' in 'utopia', but don't let the word deceive you: it's all about what's down below. It requires dirt. A ruby firmament needs something to sit atop-otherwise it'd topple. A utopia can appreciate the earthly and the humane in their raw homeliness. That is why we have the blood-stained Abattoir, the Rotten Field, the dens, and Earth-the collective name of the poorer districts-itself.

9.Maria Kaina: Precisely. This is what differentiates a utopia from a dream. There is a 'top' in 'utopia', but don't let the word deceive you: it's all about what's down below. It requires dirt. 11.Maria Kaina: A utopia needs the Cult of Bulls, a living echo of the time when the human and the bestial world sung in unison. Beastliness lies at the heart of our civilization. Dirt, blood, manure, devourment, skins, meat, and bone tools. This is what the human civilization of creators originates from.

The Settlement represents the miracle of turning a society of devourers into a society of creators. The very logic of this town's existence is a miracle in and of itself. When the process of its creation has reached a peak, the Cathedral has been built. It's been a failure though...

2.Bachelor: When will you begin to execute your design, Maria?

2.Bachelor: When will you begin to execute your design, Maria?

3.Maria Kaina: I have already begun, my Daniil... When the night falls, and the wind scatters the smoke above the scorched earth, and the dust of the buildings demolished settles, you will see several new constellations light up in the sky. They will plunge their light towards us, and when the first specks of this light reach the castellations of the Polyhedron... a miracle will happen.

3.Maria Kaina: I have already begun, my Daniil... When the night falls, and the wind scatters the smoke above the scorched earth, and the dust of the buildings demolished settles, you will see several new constellations light up in the sky. They will plunge their light towards us, and when the first specks of this light reach the castellations of the Polyhedron... a miracle will happen.

4.Bachelor: What will they be like? How are you going to call them?

4.Bachelor: What will they be like? How are you going to call them?

5.Maria Kaina: I'll see. But I expect them to be mostly red. Ruby, scarlet, crimson, carmine, merlot, mahogany, vermillion, garnet, rose, pink, burgundy... Perhaps you may even notice something familiar in the structure of these constellations.

5.Maria Kaina: I'll see. But I expect them to be mostly red. Ruby, scarlet, crimson, carmine, merlot, mahogany, vermillion, garnet, rose, pink, burgundy... Perhaps you may even notice something familiar in the structure of these constellations.

6.Bachelor: Where will these constellations come from?

6.Bachelor: Where will these constellations come from?

7.Maria Kaina: They have existed for a long time already. People just couldn't see them before because their light was hurrying towards us from far beyond. Now the first rays of these stars are about to reach our surfaces. We will see their light reflected in the specular planes of the preserved Polyhedron.

7.Maria Kaina: They have existed for a long time already. People just couldn't see them before because their light was hurrying towards us from far beyond. Now the first rays of these stars are about to reach our surfaces. We will see their light reflected in the specular planes of the preserved Polyhedron.

8.Bachelor: What will become of your family, Maria?

8.Bachelor: What will become of your family, Maria?

9.Maria Kaina: Perishing, burning down, dissolving without a trace-this is my family's destiny. It happened to my mother; it happened to Simon. Tomorrow Georgiy dies, and my father will fade out in a week. And in ten years, when my town is complete, I will pass on in the same fashion.

9.Maria Kaina: Perishing, burning down, dissolving without a trace-this is my family's destiny. It happened to my mother; it happened to Simon. Tomorrow Georgiy dies, and my father will fade out in a week. And in ten years, when my town is complete, I will pass on in the same fashion.

10.Bachelor: What will happen to the children? Will you expell them from the Tower?

10.Bachelor: What will happen to the children? Will you expell them from the Tower?

11.Maria Kaina: There's nothing to be done about it. They have to free up the space for the new guests. My brother will become embittered, betray me, and rebel against me. But I will find a way to deal with him. He will cower behind Capella's back willingly when my mother's eyes frown and glare at him!

11.Maria Kaina: There's nothing to be done about it. They have to free up the space for the new guests. My brother will become embittered, betray me, and rebel against me. But I will find a way to deal with him. He will cower behind Capella's back willingly when my mother's eyes frown and glare at him!

12.Bachelor: Have you become a Mistress already?

12.Bachelor: Have you become a Mistress already?

11.Maria Kaina: There's nothing to be done about it. They have to free up the space for the new guests. My brother will become embittered, betray me, and rebel against me. But I will find a way to deal with him. He will cower behind Capella's back willingly when my mother's eyes frown and glare at him!
